title: Introduction to Fracture Mechanics
description: Learn about the forces that cause bone fractures.

blocks.title: Course Overview
blocks.content: Welcome to the Fracture Mechanics interactive course. In this module, we will explore the four primary mechanical forces that cause bone fractures: Torsion, Compression, Tension, and Shear. Use the interactive simulations to understand how stress affects bone integrity.
Torsion occurs when a twisting force is applied to the bone, often resulting in spiral fractures. This type of injury is common in sports where the foot is planted while the body rotates.
Compression is a force that pushes or squeezes the bone along its axis. High-impact landings or falls often generate compressive forces capable of crushing bone.
Tension is a pulling force that stretches the bone. While bone is strong in compression, it is weaker in tension. Avulsion fractures are a common example where a tendon pulls a piece of bone away.
Shear force acts parallel to the cross-section of the bone, causing one part of the bone to slide against another. These forces often result in transverse fractures.
